entry.summary:
Re @hufhaus9 Devil is in the details. If blackrock doesnâ€™t own BTC. But their clients own via blackrock 51% of the network, then a hardfork would make blackrock owner and give them choice https://twitter.com/jratcliff/status/1669937251286126592?s=46&t=cM-600GJga7XNxddNsm-Pw
John W. Ratcliff:â€‚There is a strange point with the wording in that BlackRock ETF about hard forks. Traditionally, when a hard fork occurs, users get tokens on *both* forks. Large exchanges have generally honored this for custodial tokens. However, that's not what the BlackRock ETF says. It saysâ€¦ https://twitter.com/i/web/status/1669937251286126592
